questions.question_text:
A project manager is closing a project and preparing to hand it over to the operations team. During handover, a delayed invoice was submitted with a higher-than- planned cost against the project work. Consequently, project handover was delayed and the project's reported completion costs were increased.
What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?

choices.D: Captured and reviewed all of the project work and related costs regularly
choices.B: Reviewed the total committed cost against the cost invoiced at project closing
choices.A: Notified all vendors about the invoicing and nonpayment deadlines
choices.C: Involved the finance team and discussed the issue with the vendor

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In conclusion, the correct answer, D, suggests that by regularly capturing and reviewing project work and related costs before the situation occurs, the project manager could have identified and addressed discrepancies or issues early, ultimately preventing the delayed invoice and increased costs during project handover.

All other answers refer to after the problem occurs this is the only solution that addresses before a problem which is what the question asked.

The main issue here is a defect in monotoring process activities. Along the project life cycle, the project manager and team have to continually perform M&C activities on cost, schedule, quality, resource, risks and scope. The scenario discribes a predictive approach with a one time deliverable at the end of the project so constant feedback from customer isn't possible. In such an approach, it's key to monitor the above contstraints regularly through out the different phases. As such continously analysing the impact on and balancing constraints in case a modification is done or a change controle process is innitiated and completed due to variances observed due to monotoring that where beyond acceptable levels.

How should the project manager approach this?

choices.B: Tell the owner that a rough order of magnitude will be provided
choices.D: Tell the owner that the task requires more time and expertise
choices.A: Call a meeting with the project team to identify the most appropriate approach
choices.C: Contact a subject matter expert (SME) for advice and consultation

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
A team can be relocated and occupied, how to gather it within 4 hours? the expected answer is based on the knowledge of an order of magnitude at the beginning of a new project -25 / +75%, answer B

comments.content: But as a thumb rule , shouldn't any estimates involve the team collaboration or team consultation as they are the ones who execute the work. ?

discussion.content: Answer B is the most appropriate in this situation. The project manager should inform the owner that a rough order of magnitude will be provided. This approach will give the owner an initial idea of the costs involved, but it will not be a detailed estimate. The project manager can then work with the project team and subject matter experts to refine the estimate and provide a more accurate cost estimate. Calling a meeting, contacting a subject matter expert, or telling the owner that the task requires more time and expertise will not help the project manager to complete the task within the given timeframe.

Selected Answer: A
How could the project manager conclude that he would provide the "rough" order of magnitude? The team might be able to prepare a more accurate estimate in a short amount of time. Therefore, he should convene a meeting first to discuss the best path forward with the team.

DRAG DROP -
A company has created a cross-functional team to drive the digital transformation project for the business. The team is expected to deliver the minimum viable product (MVP) that addresses market need in the shortest possible time.
Match the roles for the team on the left to their corresponding responsibilities on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

choices.B: Select the same stakeholders for the next project to avoid doing knowledge transfer.
choices.D: Request the PMO to manage the lessons learned repository.
choices.A: Engage key stakeholders to complete and deliver lessons learned.
choices.C: Present the project achievements and delegate knowledge transfer to the steering committee.

discussion.content:
A. Engage key stakeholders to complete and deliver lessons learned.
Engaging key stakeholders to complete and deliver lessons learned ensures that valuable insights and experiences from the completed project are captured and shared. This process helps in improving future projects by avoiding past mistakes and leveraging successful practices.
Not D. because while the PMO might manage the repository, it is the project manager's responsibility to ensure lessons learned are documented and shared effectively. The PMO managing the repository does not replace the need for active engagement with stakeholders to capture these lessons.
why not D? - phatct2

Selected Answer: A
A. Engage key stakeholders to complete and deliver lessons learned
